last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
In the moment, depending on how vile it is and how lost in the sauce the person is, you could

>flip out at them (which in my case, at least, is unlikely to do anything but reinforce stereotypes)
>behave in a way that contradicts whatever they think of you in an attempt to break them out of their misperception (may end up eating you up inside, that you have to do that)
>ignore them entirely as though they are a misbehaving child (may be better for the self-esteem, some people are embarrassing enough to keep going)
I guess you have to customize it to whatever people think of you and whatever hurts or bolsters your pride.

In general, I'll devote a little energy to the other person if they're not clearly unrecoverable, and just do something that deflates whatever they had going. Sometimes I lose it, though. I told someone recently in one of those "you're dirt with a 10 IQ" interactions that I was a sentient being with feelings recently and then left. I didn't like that loss of emotional control.

When I get home I do things to distract me or consume media that has people like me just living normal lives in it. I take care of myself, I do work. That part is much more important. The reasons for people to be like this are a little bigger than just my walk to the grocery store, so I don't expect to change things dramatically at that time. I change myself so I can deal with it, and I tell myself I've been dealing with it for decades now.

Peace, man. Sorry about it.

This depends. If you have installed their app on your phone or it's connected to their MDM through a BYOD policy then yes. Otherwise, if it's just your phone without any of their stuff on it and you're using a third party data source I'm not sure by what mechanism you imagine that might even be possible.

You can't sniff cellular packets in the same way you can wifi. To be clear, you can still sniff them but the method is different and it's very illegal. That's a wiretap under the law, we're talking serious jail time for doing it if you aren't a member of law enforcement with a court issued warrant.

>>27762960
>>27762964

If you're connected to the employers wifi they can see all of your traffic just as a base log. There's really no effort involved in this, it's part of the panel for pretty much every enterprise grade router/firewall/switch/WAP manufacturer

TLS ("https") doesn't prevent deep packet inspection from inside the destination or source network. Heck, it doesn't even prevent deep packet inspection from your ISP. This is trivial and is again included in the panel for every enterprise grade appliance manufacturer. Fortinet even email a weekly report of interesting results from DPI.

Even some higher end consumer grade all in one gateways can do deep packet inspection over TLS. It's trivial.

So, in summary:

Connected to cellular as a member of the employers MDM, they can see traffic

Connected to cellular not as a member of the employers MDM, they can't see traffic

Connected to wifi and everyone authed on the network can see everything you do, including passwords you send even with TLS.

Connected to wifi and encrypting your traffic through a VPN and they can't see but everyone on the VPN can.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Depends on your situation.

If you're at uni or you're trying to break into the industry unpaid internships are worth it for the experience and the people you meet.

If it's at an aspirational employer, it's also highly worth it for not only the above reasons but because it looks amazing on your CV.

If you've been in the industry for awhile and have experience, but you find yourself between jobs, an unpaid internship isn't worthwhile. It's better to look to volunteer work to keep your gaps closed if that's what you're looking to do.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
You can't get excused after jury selection.

It depends on where you live, but the trick is to show up very early, wait until the right moment, then approach the person in charge and be super respectful and deferential. Tell them you need an extension but missed the deadline (there was probably an online form) because you thought you would be able to serve. They probably won't ask about your situation, but if they do, be prepared with a good reason. A true one. If you lie about this now, sooner or later you'll be breaking the law in order to lie.

If it's not a child or a potentially dangerous hardship, you're probably going to have to serve.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27763233
Really strange. I got summoned for jury selection. That's what happens. You get a summons in the mail telling you to show up at the court house, room #, at a certain time, with a bunch of other people. Then both sides' attorneys ask people questions to see who to disqualify or keep. I haven't heard of juries being chosen any other way.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Don't try to come across as biased, and don't claim any sort of mental or emotional problem. They don't care, because this is for the lawyers to decide, and at the end of the day you're not going to lie in court. It needs to be about the hardship your serving will cause to someone else.

For what it's worth, my first excusal was in New York because I was the main caregiver to a young child. My second was in California and similar but the hardship was to an understaffed business with no time to train a replacement.

>>27763070
A 401k is literally through your company. No company, no 401k. Now if you mean a brokerage account or IRA than just find a brokerage service like Fidelity and set up an account. As for investments try some mutual funds and if you want more choice some try index fund etfs that follow broad industries like automotive or electronics or “female led” businesses. You can find index funds for anything. The idea behind an etf or mutual fund is simply put a bunch of people pooling their money for an expert to pick stocks. So some gug in a suit is deciding what stocks the fund buys and and sells and you make profits (or lose money) based on the trades.

As for what to choose
>Always invest the maximum you can or your company matches in your 401k. If your company matches up to $10k per year than always try to put $10k into it every year
>If you still have spare money open an IRA and invest up to 6000 (maximum allowed) per year
>If you still have leftover you want to invest open a brokerage account

If you want to take more risks take them with the brokerage account as those gains are taxed yearly and losses can be written off. So if you’re like “I really want to buy Tesla (or Gamestop or Nvidia) stock” than buy it through your brokerage account.

>>27762869
Look into different ADHD meds, not everything works the same for everyone. And the best treatment isn't just meds, it's holistic: CBT to unlearn maladaptive coping mechanisms you've developed, and trauma therapy to help you work through all the incessantly negative experiences that happen to most people with long time undiagnosed ADHD. ADHD often is comorbid with other conditions like PTSD (it makes sense, being undiagnosed means that chaos and bad experiences are plenty, especially if both parent and child have it, due to bad impulse control, frustration from not having your shit together, always being told "you could achieve so much more if you just put in the effort", and a whole bucket list of shit undiagnosed ADHD leads to). The point being that meds usually help, but they're not gonna resolve stuff by themselves. If your doctor is like "take these pills and be done with it" he or she is frankly a shitty excuse for a doctor. Look into different things you can do yourself also; there's a great book by two doctors who are specialised in treating ADHD and have it themselves, so they have both the medical professionals' and the patient's perspective. The book is "ADHD 2.0" by Edward Hallowell and John Ratey. If it IS adult ADHD in your case there's a lot that can be done about it, but finding a competent doctor can be a struggle. Look into ones that specialize in ADHD in adults.

If she came from a trailer park family who doesn't value even basic education or anything, or at least learnt to value it in her own, then she will be the type who probably won't practice reading with the kids or even teach them basic counting or ABCs.
